principles.name: Self-Employment Influence as Foundation
principles.description: 'My dad being self-employed was a factor. I think seeing a couple of brothers who own businesses was a factor.' These early exposures to entrepreneurship shaped fundamental perspectives on work and autonomy.

principles.name: Intentional Problem Creation for Stimulation
principles.description: 'I can get... I did get bored easily to the point where if I had the opportunity to break something, I would. That way, I had something else to do or to push just to go do something new.' Boredom drives destructive behavior to create new challenges.

principles.name: Corporate Cycle Monotony Recognition
principles.description: 'I view company life as pretty much a 12-month cycle, and not that much new happens year to year... You're doing the same shit every 12 months. You're just maybe doing it with more people, fewer people, bigger budget, smaller budget. You're still doing the same shit.'

principles.name: Need for External Stimulation
principles.description: 'I need that phone to ring because it's nothing to do.' The requirement for external, unpredictable inputs to maintain engagement and energy.

patterns.name: Boredom-Driven Disruption
patterns.description: When organizational work becomes predictable, intentionally create problems or disruptions to generate new challenges and maintain engagement.
patterns.context: Corporate or structured environments where routine work cycles create understimulation for high-need-for-variety personalities.

patterns.name: External Variety Dependency
patterns.description: Require external, unpredictable inputs (like phone calls or new problems) to maintain energy and interest in work.
patterns.context: Professional situations where internal motivation is insufficient and external stimulation is needed for sustained performance.

examples.name: Early Business Exposure Foundation
examples.content: Dan identifies formative influences as 'my dad being self-employed' and 'seeing a couple of brothers who own businesses' as factors that shaped his approach to work and business.

examples.name: Corporate Boredom and Disruption Pattern
examples.content: Dan describes getting 'bored easily to the point where if I had the opportunity to break something, I would. That way, I had something else to do or to push just to go do something new.' He views 'company life as pretty much a 12-month cycle' where 'not that much new happens year to year.'

examples.name: Realization About External Stimulation Need
examples.content: When leaving Macy's for public accounting, a friend said 'I get why you left, but you are where you need to be.' This led to the realization 'I need that phone to ring because it's nothing to do' - recognizing the need for external stimulation and variety.

principles.name: Crisis Perspective Management
principles.description: When crisis hits, 'communicate through words or behavior that we're not looking at something that is the end of the world. It is important and it needs to be dealt with, but we're going to take a beat to make sure that we understand it and then move forward.'

principles.name: Collaborative Crisis Response
principles.description: Crisis flow state involves 'go into collaborator mode' where 'I'm not really head down trying to do it myself, but I'm trying to take in as much information as I can on the crisis.' For crises, 'it tends not to be directive.'

patterns.name: Crisis Information Gathering
patterns.description: Immediately shift into 'collaborator mode' and rapidly solicit opinions from people and sources, prioritizing information intake over individual problem-solving.
patterns.context: Acute crisis situations requiring immediate response, where collaborative intelligence gathering is more effective than individual analysis.

patterns.name: Calm-Then-Collaborate Sequence
patterns.description: First establish perspective that the crisis is manageable, then 'take a beat to make sure that we understand it' before moving into collaborative information gathering mode.
patterns.context: High-pressure situations where team emotional regulation is crucial for effective crisis response.

examples.name: Tuesday Crisis Response Pattern
examples.content: When a crisis happens on a Tuesday requiring immediate response, Dan's innate response is to first communicate that 'we're not looking at something that is the end of the world' while acknowledging its importance, then shift into collaborative mode to rapidly gather information rather than working alone.

principles.name: Daily Financial Foundation Reliance
principles.description: 'I go back to the financial foundation almost every day, whether I want to or not.' The accounting/CPA background provides constant practical value regardless of conscious intent to use it.

principles.name: Small Business Owner Knowledge Gap Recognition
principles.description: The accounting foundation is valuable 'because it's knowledge that most small business owners don't have.' This creates a consistent competitive advantage and value proposition.

principles.name: Elevated Status Through Association
principles.description: Working at Arthur Anderson provided 'elevated status' in Cincinnati because 'if you worked there, you had an elevated status.' This early credibility foundation influences ongoing professional positioning.

patterns.name: Financial Foundation as Constant Resource
patterns.description: Leverage financial and accounting knowledge as a daily, automatic resource that provides value even when not consciously deployed.
patterns.context: Business consulting or advisory work where financial literacy provides consistent analytical advantage over business owners who lack this background.

patterns.name: Credibility Through Prestigious Association
patterns.description: Use early association with prestigious organizations (like major accounting firms) to establish ongoing credibility and elevated status in professional relationships.
patterns.context: Professional services where client confidence is influenced by past institutional affiliations and credentials.

examples.name: Accounting Foundation as Daily Tool
examples.content: Dan identifies his 'master's in accounting, CPA, and working at a large public accounting CPA firm' as the foundation he returns to 'almost every day, whether I want to or not.' This knowledge is valuable 'because it's knowledge that most small business owners don't have.'

examples.name: Arthur Anderson Elevated Status
examples.content: Working at Arthur Anderson, 'one of the largest firms in the world,' provided elevated status in Cincinnati where 'if you worked there, you had an elevated status,' establishing early credibility that influences ongoing professional positioning.

principles.name: Professional Circle Exposure as Learning Catalyst
principles.description: 'The exposure of working with various attorneys in thirty different states... you just get to know them, and you go out to dinner and things like that. You just learn a lot, not about law and taxes, but in everything. You learn from them.' This broad professional exposure creates knowledge beyond core competencies.

principles.name: Judgment Over Technical Skills Application
principles.description: At the Limited, 'being a CPA wasn't that important... It was more about just taking that. I was making a lot of their judgments on appeals and litigation and everything. So it was more about judgment than anything versus advising a client.'

principles.name: Big Company Perspective as Small Business Advantage
principles.description: 'I can bring them a big company and big CPA firm perspective that they otherwise don't get.' The combination of large organization experience applied to small business contexts creates unique value.

principles.name: Responsibility Progression Through Specialization
principles.description: Career progression from 'super specialist' at big CPA firm where 'I was a step removed from helping them' to Limited where 'I'm still a specialist, but I have greater responsibility.'

patterns.name: Cross-Professional Learning Integration
patterns.description: Actively absorb knowledge from diverse professional contacts beyond core technical areas, using social interactions to build broader perspective.
patterns.context: Professional roles involving extensive interaction with experts from other fields, where relationship-building creates learning opportunities.

patterns.name: Large Organization Experience Translation
patterns.description: Apply big company systems, perspectives, and judgment frameworks to small business contexts where such sophistication is typically unavailable.
patterns.context: Consulting or advisory work with smaller organizations that lack access to enterprise-level thinking and processes.

examples.name: Attorney Network Learning Experience
examples.content: At the Limited, Dan gained 'exposure of working with various attorneys in thirty different states' and learning from them during dinners and social interactions. He notes 'you just learn a lot, not about law and taxes, but in everything' and that 'most attorneys are huge history buffs' who know their local history extensively.

examples.name: Big Company Perspective Advantage
examples.content: Dan's career progression from large CPA firm specialist to Limited corporate role to local CPA firm allows him to 'bring them a big company and big CPA firm perspective that they otherwise don't get' when working with small businesses.

principles.name: Professionalism as Dedication, Not Rigidity
principles.description: 'The importance of moving your company toward professionalism and not just... I don't mean rigidity either, but I mean professionalism in the sense of a dedication that it's worth it, but it's really freaking heart. That's why they are where they are.'
principles.theme: Scaling Enterprise Discipline to Small Business

principles.name: Scalable Discipline Principles
principles.description: Large organizations succeed through 'discipline that was non-negotiable for them.' Small businesses can adopt this discipline even without the same resources: 'we can't do it. We don't have the resources that they do. But they knew their numbers and they knew this and they knew that.'
principles.theme: Scaling Enterprise Discipline to Small Business

principles.name: Decentralized Success Model Translation
principles.description: At The Limited, 'individual divisions just running their own business' provides a model for small businesses: 'I know how this $500 million business ran. They ran their own.' This shows scalable principles regardless of size.
principles.theme: Scaling Enterprise Discipline to Small Business

patterns.name: Professional Discipline Translation
patterns.description: Extract the discipline and knowledge management practices from large organizations and adapt them for small business contexts, focusing on core principles rather than resource-dependent systems.
patterns.context: Small business consulting where introducing enterprise-level discipline around metrics, processes, and accountability can drive significant improvement.
patterns.theme: Scaling Enterprise Discipline to Small Business

patterns.name: Division-Level Business Model Application
patterns.description: Use examples of how large company divisions operate independently to show small businesses that sophisticated business practices are achievable at their scale.
patterns.context: Situations where small business owners believe professional management practices are only for large companies.
patterns.theme: Scaling Enterprise Discipline to Small Business

examples.name: Limited Division Model for Small Business
examples.content: Dan uses his experience at The Limited, where 'individual divisions just running their own business' in a decentralized structure, to help small businesses. He tells them 'I know how this $500 million business ran. They ran their own. Yeah, we can't do it. We don't have the resources that they do. But they knew their numbers and they knew this and they knew that.' The key is adopting 'discipline that was non-negotiable for them.'
examples.theme: Scaling Enterprise Discipline to Small Business

principles.name: Being Right Isn't Always the Goal
principles.description: 'Heads and shoulders above all is... Being right isn't always the goal.' This represents a fundamental shift from rightness-based decision making to outcome-based flexibility.
principles.theme: Evolution from Rigidity to Adaptive Flexibility

principles.name: Rigidity as Professional Liability
principles.description: Past approach was to 'base decisions and actions on what is right' which caused internal fury and detachment when things seemed wrong. This rigidity 'would just set me up to fail' and 'end up pissing her off because I wasn't doing it her way, even though it was wrong.'
principles.theme: Evolution from Rigidity to Adaptive Flexibility

principles.name: Client Method Acceptance
principles.description: 'I literally don't worry about it with clients anymore. They're go to do' what they want to do. This acceptance prevents the internal conflict that previously caused detachment and relationship damage.
principles.theme: Evolution from Rigidity to Adaptive Flexibility

principles.name: Job Security Through Flexibility
principles.description: Learning flexibility 'in part, for job security' represents a practical adaptation where survival required abandoning rigid righteousness in favor of relationship preservation.
principles.theme: Evolution from Rigidity to Adaptive Flexibility

patterns.name: Rigidity-to-Flexibility Evolution
patterns.description: Evolve from basing decisions on 'what is right' to accepting client preferences, even when they seem wrong, to preserve relationships and effectiveness.
patterns.context: Professional services where client relationships and outcomes matter more than being technically correct or morally superior.
patterns.theme: Evolution from Rigidity to Adaptive Flexibility

patterns.name: Internal Detachment Prevention
patterns.description: Avoid the cycle of internal fury and detachment that comes from focusing on rightness when working with less sophisticated decision-makers.
patterns.context: Working with business owners or leaders who lack technical expertise but have final decision authority.
patterns.theme: Evolution from Rigidity to Adaptive Flexibility

examples.name: Sawmill Owner Jo Relationship Learning
examples.content: At the sawmill, owner Jo 'wasn't very sophisticated or understanding of business or finance' and 'would just want what she wanted.' Dan's insistence on doing what was 'right' would 'just set me up to fail' and 'end up pissing her off because I wasn't doing it her way, even though it was wrong.' This taught him flexibility over rigidity.
examples.theme: Evolution from Rigidity to Adaptive Flexibility

examples.name: The Limited Internal Fury Pattern
examples.content: At The Limited, when Dan thought something was wrong, he 'would be furious internally, and it would cause me to lose interest for a period of time. I would almost become detached because I didn't want to have anything to do with it.' This pattern of rigidity became professionally limiting.
examples.theme: Evolution from Rigidity to Adaptive Flexibility

principles.name: Context-Dependent Empathy Development
principles.description: Empathy wasn't needed at The Limited because 'everyone in our department, we were all the same, and they were very much black and white, but a big company. There's not a lot of gray.' But at the family sawmill 'they're gray all over the place' requiring empathy to manage effectively.

principles.name: Holistic People Assessment
principles.description: At the sawmill, managing people requires understanding they're 'in rural Indiana. They're not very well educated. They work hard as hell, but some of these guys are learnedly farmers. They've already been up five hours. So you have to put all that together when you're thinking about people's performance.'

principles.name: People-Centered Problem Solving
principles.description: 'When you're working with any small business owner, one of the problems eventually becomes people. If your solution to everything is firearms or something like that, then you're not really helping them solve the problem.' Solutions must account for human complexity.

principles.name: People-Centered Identity
principles.description: When asked to articulate his holistic approach as a soft skill, Dan states simply 'I am people-centered.'

patterns.name: Environmental Context Integration
patterns.description: Assess employee performance by integrating their full life context - education level, work ethic, background, and daily circumstances before work begins.
patterns.context: Managing diverse workforces, particularly in rural or blue-collar environments where workers' backgrounds significantly impact their work performance and needs.

patterns.name: People-First Solution Design
patterns.description: Ensure business solutions account for human complexity rather than defaulting to simple disciplinary or systematic fixes.
patterns.context: Small business consulting where people issues are inevitable and solutions must work with human nature rather than against it.

examples.name: Rural Indiana Sawmill Empathy Learning
examples.content: At the family sawmill, Dan had to develop empathy because workers were 'in rural Indiana. They're not very well educated. They work hard as hell, but some of these guys are learnedly farmers. They've already been up five hours.' This required putting 'all that together when you're thinking about people's performance' - a stark contrast to The Limited where everyone was 'black and white.'

examples.name: People-Centered Problem Solving Philosophy
examples.content: Dan explains that in small business consulting, 'one of the problems eventually becomes people. If your solution to everything is firearms or something like that, then you're not really helping them solve the problem.' When asked to name this soft skill, he identifies as 'people-centered.'

principles.name: Family as Perspective Transformer
principles.description: 'Being a parent of three with now six grandchildren, it gives you a completely different perspective on things.' This family experience fundamentally alters how one approaches work and problems.

principles.name: Grandchildren as Mental Recharge Vehicle
principles.description: 'What the grandkids serve as in effect is they're like the recharge vehicle, mental. I can take on other people's problems all day long and help as much as I can and produce data or whatever they want. But then, at the end of the day, if you stop by and see some of the kids, you're forced to comment on how pretty the dresses that they're wearing today is an exact copy from some Disney movie.'

principles.name: Forced Attention Shift for Grounding
principles.description: 'By moving all of your attention over there, even if it's for a short period of time, probably healthy, maybe keeps you more grounded.' The complete attention shift from business problems to simple, present-moment interactions with children provides psychological balance.

patterns.name: Total Attention Shifting
patterns.description: Use interactions with grandchildren to completely shift attention from complex business problems to simple, present-moment experiences like commenting on Disney dresses.
patterns.context: High-stress professional work that requires periodic mental breaks and grounding through completely different types of human interaction.

patterns.name: Family-Based Mental Recharging
patterns.description: Leverage family relationships, particularly with grandchildren, as a systematic way to restore mental energy after taking on others' problems professionally.
patterns.context: Consulting or advisory work where emotional and mental energy is constantly given to solve others' problems, requiring intentional restoration methods.

examples.name: Grandchildren as Mental Recharge
examples.content: Dan describes his six grandchildren as 'the recharge vehicle, mental' where after taking on 'other people's problems all day long,' stopping by to see the kids forces him to focus on simple things like 'how pretty the dresses that they're wearing today is an exact copy from some Disney movie.' This complete attention shift 'probably healthy, maybe keeps you more grounded.'

principles.name: Early Leadership Reality - Not Everyone Wants to be Led
principles.description: Class president experience taught 'at an early age... that you can't lead all people? Some people don't want to be led.' This fundamental leadership reality was learned through direct experience in high school.

principles.name: Team Success Over Personal Gain
principles.description: As soccer coach, 'you're trying to figure out how to orchestrate this mess for the greater good. It wasn't for my greater good. It was really for the team's success.' Leadership focused on collective outcomes rather than personal benefit.

principles.name: Collaboration-Authority Balance
principles.description: 'If you're a coach and you're not a collaborator, I suspect that you're not very successful.' However, 'sometimes, you had to put your foot down and all that. So, that's that. That balance.' Leadership requires both collaborative and authoritative approaches.

principles.name: Authority Despite Age/Experience Disadvantage
principles.description: As 'a freshman coach to 22 women, most of whom were older than me, it was quite telling' - learning to lead people with more experience and maturity created early lessons in authority without traditional credentials.

patterns.name: Early Leadership Responsibility Seeking
patterns.description: Consistently take on leadership roles from high school through college, creating situations where 'people relying on me' becomes a pattern.
patterns.context: Personal development where leadership skills are built through volunteering for responsibility rather than waiting for appointment.

patterns.name: Leading Up and Across Experience Gaps
patterns.description: Learn to lead people who are older, more experienced, or in peer relationships where formal authority is limited.
patterns.context: Situations where leadership must be earned through competence and collaboration rather than granted through hierarchical position.

examples.name: High School Class President Leadership Lessons
examples.content: Dan was class president for 'three or four years' in high school, missing only junior year because he 'didn't run' due to other commitments. This experience taught him early 'that you can't lead all people? Some people don't want to be led.'

examples.name: College Soccer Coach Collaboration Challenge
examples.content: As women's soccer coach in college, Dan had to 'orchestrate this mess for the greater good' focused on 'the team's success' rather than personal gain. As 'a freshman coach to 22 women, most of whom were older than me,' he learned that successful coaching requires being 'a collaborator' while also knowing when to 'put your foot down.'

principles.name: Family Over Career Priority Decision
principles.description: 'I was clearly putting the family ahead of my career. What I should just say is what I thought was best for the family.' This represents a fundamental values-based decision that shaped future operating principles.
principles.theme: Values-Based Life Decisions and Community Commitment

principles.name: Big Company Breathlessness Recognition
principles.description: 'I'd been there nine years, and I was breathless. So, I turned down other opportunities because my whole family was here' - recognizing when career progression conflicts with personal well-being and family priorities.
principles.theme: Values-Based Life Decisions and Community Commitment

principles.name: Long-term Thinking Over Short-term Gain
principles.description: 'I thought in the long run, the kids would thrive back here or do better' - prioritizing long-term family outcomes over immediate career advancement opportunities.
principles.theme: Values-Based Life Decisions and Community Commitment

principles.name: Finality and Root-Setting
principles.description: 'Moving back felt final, meaning I never put down roots in Columbus. So, that's a very local feeling.' The decision represented commitment to place and community rather than career mobility.
principles.theme: Values-Based Life Decisions and Community Commitment

patterns.name: Values-Based Career Decision Making
patterns.description: Make major career decisions based on family and personal values rather than purely professional advancement opportunities.
patterns.context: Career transition points where professional opportunities conflict with personal or family priorities.
patterns.theme: Values-Based Life Decisions and Community Commitment

patterns.name: Community Root-Setting
patterns.description: Choose to establish deep community roots rather than remaining mobile for career advancement, accepting the finality of geographic commitment.
patterns.context: Mid-career decisions where establishing stability and community connection becomes more important than career flexibility.
patterns.theme: Values-Based Life Decisions and Community Commitment

examples.name: Cincinnati Return Decision
examples.content: Dan left The Limited after nine years, feeling 'breathless' at the 'big, dumb company.' He was 'clearly putting the family ahead of my career' by moving back to Cincinnati where 'my whole family was here.' He believed 'in the long run, the kids would thrive back here or do better' and it 'turned out to be just absolutely the right decision.'
examples.theme: Values-Based Life Decisions and Community Commitment

examples.name: Finality of Root-Setting
examples.content: The move back to Cincinnati 'felt final, meaning I never put down roots in Columbus.' This represents a commitment to place and community over career mobility, which Dan describes as 'a very local feeling' but 'kind of important.'
examples.theme: Values-Based Life Decisions and Community Commitment
